title: Subinterval
text: The first step is to divide the interval from $$0$$ to $$1$$ into $$n$$ equal subintervals. These subintervals can be seen as rectangles.
speech: The first step is to divide the interval from , 0  to  1  into  n  equal subintervals. These subintervals can be seen as rectangles.

to   1

equal subintervals. These subintervals can be seen as rectangles.

title: Subinterval
text: How many subinterval or rectangle can we create in this problem?

subHints.title: Subinterval
subHints.text: Since $$n=4$$ is given in this problem, we can divide the interval from $$x=0$$ to $$x=1$$ into $$4$$ rectangles.

speech: How many subinterval or rectangle can we create in this problem?
pacedSpeech: How many subinterval or rectangle can we create in this problem?

title: Find the step size
text: The step size or width of the rectangles can be found using $$Δx=\frac{b-a}{n}$$ where $$b$$ is the upper bound, a is the lower bound and $$n$$ is the number of rectangles.
speech: The step size or width of the rectangles can be found using    delta x, is equal to fraction, b minus a, over n,   where  b  is the upper bound, a is the lower bound and  n  is the number of rectangles.

where   b
is the upper bound, a is the lower bound and   n
is the number of rectangles.

title: Find the step size
text: For the $$4$$ rectangles, each rectangle has a width of $$Δx=\frac{1-0}{4}=0.25$$

title: Right-endpoint approximation
text: The right rectangle approximation is when you make the right hand points of the pieces the height of the rectangles. In other words, the height of each rectangle is equal to the value of the function at the right endpoint of its base.
speech: The right rectangle approximation is when you make the right hand points of the pieces the height of the rectangles. In other words, the height of each rectangle is equal to the value of the function at the right endpoint of its base.
pacedSpeech: The right rectangle approximation is when you make the right hand points of the pieces the height of the rectangles. In other words, the height of each rectangle is equal to the value of the function at the right endpoint of its base.

title: Right-endpoint approximation
text: Using the right-endpoint approximation, what is the height of a rectangle in the interval $$[0.25, 0.5]$$ ?
speech: Using the right-endpoint approximation, what is the height of a rectangle in the interval  the closed interval from 0.25 to 0.5  ?
pacedSpeech: Using the right-endpoint approximation, what is the height of a rectangle in the interval   the closed interval from 0.25 to 0.5

title: Right-endpoint approximation
text: Using a right-endpoint approximation, the heights are $$f(0.25)=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$$, $$f(0.5)=0$$, $$f(0.75)=\frac{-\sqrt{2}}{2}$$, $$f(1)=-1$$

title: Find the area of the rectangles
text: With the width and height just found, we can easily find the area of each rectangle using area of a rectangle formula $$A=w h$$ then add all of them up to get an approximation for the area under the curve.
speech: With the width and height just found, we can easily find the area of each rectangle using area of a rectangle formula ,   a is equal to w h  then add all of them up to get an approximation for the area under the curve.

title: Approximating the Area
text: Starting with $$x=0.25$$ from the righ-hand point of the first rectangles, we have $$A=f{\left(x_1\right)} \Delta x+f{\left(x_2\right)} \Delta x+f{\left(x_3\right)} \Delta x+f{\left(x_4\right)} \Delta x=\Delta x \left(f{\left(x_1\right)}+f{\left(x_2\right)}+f{\left(x_3\right)}+f{\left(x_4\right)}\right)$$
